element_texts.text: Completed

Northfield, Sept 24th 1847
Well, at last, after so long waiting and suspense, Mr A.F. Edwards now informs me that I can have a situation upon the Vermont and Masachusetts Rail Road as an [unclear] Engineer. And to begin in a day or two. Probably Monday or Tuesday of next week. So I can not well have time to return to Bangor or any where else for my fixings and must have my trunk sent on in the best possible manner by express perhaps. You know best how as far as Boston. - After that, "Fitchburg Railroad, via Baldwinsville, to Northfield." I Shall not be at Northfield probably but I do not yet know where I shall be, and at any rate I can get it from here.
Completed

K. White
My trunk you know is in the garrett chamber, over your stove. However, now I think of it there are some things perhaps that are over at Milo[?] and ought to be in the trunk. Which can easily be arranged as I have here one key of the trunk and the other I left not with you I think, but with Lucy at Milo[?] I will write immediately to her and you send not the trunk until she has time to forward to you whatever ought to be inserted. 
I guess the best way for the trunk to come would be Bangor and Boston Express to the Quincy House, Boston, (Brattleboro Express Depot) By the Express (Brattleboro Express) of H. White) 
The Express [unclear] to Brattleboro, and I shall probably be nearer Brattleboro than Northfield. (Quincy House Boston, Whites' Express, Brattleboro")
The Greatest trouble is do not know exactly what to write to Lucy that I want. 
I expect I can get along a few days,even as an Engineer, without my trunk I must buy a coat and [unclear] boots to begin with. 
Monday of this week I went over to Winchester to see cousin Josiah K Metcaff now teaching [unclear] school these stopped gone twenty four hours.
Completed

Tuesday PM went over the Warwick Uncle Williams, T. E. Baldwin, Lucy's Mans there. B. and I went Wed. A.M. upon Mt. Grace. The greatest, by far, of all my experiences of mountain climbing and scenery. It was splendid.
I expect, by the time I get fairly at work on the Rail Road I shall want awfully to down to Bangor.
Perhaps I will write to Lucy to night have everything made ready to send my trunk just as soon as possible, but not sent it for a day or two until I write, so you may know better where.
Aff. I. T. Metcalfe
Completed

Brattleboro', Sept. 27th, 1847
Dear Brother,
I believe it is not long since I directed a letter to you, but as I promised to write again, I fear you will not send on my trunk without further order.
The trunk should be sent to this place as soon as convenient, Directed -- I. S. Metcalf, Brattleboro' Vt. Care of White's Express, No. 3, Fannel Hall Boston. To which place you can send it as you think best, by express, I suppose. If the Bangor Express delivers it at No. 3, Fannel Hall, Boston, White's Express will pay their bills and charge it upon the trunk here.
Perhaps it would be worth the while, for correctness and safety, to write my mail at the same time that you forward.
I shall probably commence operations an Wednesday, near here. Whether I shall
Completed

be working towards Troy N.Y. or Bellon's Fall is by me not certainly now known; I think likely though towards N.Y. over the mountains.
Brattleboro' is quite a place, more than I expected -- flourishing -- destined to be more so. These Rail Roads are great things -- strange our Down East people do not get their eyes open to them a little more than they have.
Do write to me how everything gets along. You cannot imagine how anxious I am getting to be to hear from some of you.
Whether I shall have time & opportunity to write I know not. Old Edwards asked me Sat. if I thought I could stand it to "Camp Our"? What would you have told him? Ha!
I tried to get me a coat in Northfield the other day. Could not get up one that would answer my purpose
Completed

at a[n]y reasonable rate, if at all. To day I find one in Brattleboro that does me fairly for $5.00!
I expected to give 7.00 or 9.00
Tell Eliah to write to me.
I wish I could receive my trunk Sat. night. It would be very great convenience to me. If not Thursday of next week. I suppose if you can get it to Boston Friday night next do it -- if not -- thereafter.
Affectionately
I. S. Metcalf
Forwarded by
Jerome's Express
Oct 4th 1847
Completed

Isaac
Sep. 27 1847
Forwarding trunk to Vt.
Mr. J. M. Metcalf
Bangor
Maine
Completed

Northfield Monday morn. Oct. 11th 47
Dear Joseph
I have got up before the engineers.
I believe I shall send on this letter with others this morning.
I do not know whether we shall start for Bennington to day, or not.
At any rate I think I shall continue to go as far as Brattleboro', so as to get hold of my trunk, which I have not yet seen.
If I find it in Brattleboro', well & good; I'll write to inform you.
If, by any possibility, it is not there, I do not know what I shall, or can do. At any rate I should write to you fore soon.
Write to me all the newz and everything else Joseph, Eliah, Arnie[?].
Be good boys, Mind your health, your business, and your characters, and may the Lord preserve, protect, and bless you & all,
Aff. I. S. Metcalf
Completed

Brattleboro' Vermont. Sunday, October 31st, 1847
Contrary to my usual practice, it is now, I believe, nearly a whole fortnight since I have written home. However, I presume I need makes no excuse therefor, as it is about three weeks since I have received a letter, or heard a word from DOWN EAST. Alfred R. Field Esq., my present immediate superior, has gone down to Northfield to day, and I expect will bring me upon his return about a dozen letters, If he does not, I have made up my mind to be considerably vexed with the inhabitants of Maine. Now, if I were at home, i think I could find a good deal to write to @ poor scamp[?] so far off which would interest him; knowing as well as I do that every thing I could write would be interesting to him.
But now, I have quite a mind to give up  writing altogether, as others do. I can of course have nothing of importance to write, merely how I myself am getting on. To be sure, it might be a matter of curiosity simply for people at home to hear once in a while what a fellow was about or whether he was about anything; but then it is of mo sort of consequence: it can make no difference: he gets along just as well, whether they know it or even think of it. On the whole perhaps it would be better to write only once a year! And none of you ever write to me, I may adopt that course!
Completed

In pursuance of this plan I am writing this letter, you see! I am getting along finely in my profession, in fact, much beyond my expectations. What my wages may be I do not know. Perhaps with my opportunities for advancement, I ought to be satisfied without wages at all. At present prospects I shall be capable enough by next Spring to be worth about fifty dollars per month. Circumstances on this road have been just such that I have been put forward so far just as fast as i could wish it. Most, in commencing the business are obliged to serve in some inferior capacity for a year of two at least. perhaps carry a rod for the Level for a year or two without ever getting hold of the instrument itself, or any other instrument. I have now been on the road about a month, instead of being confined to one inferior employment. I have had opportunity to become acquainted with many. In fact, feel already quite familiar with the whole business of Engineering, as far as concerns the surveying & laying out of a road preparatory to building it., preparatory to the work of the paddies. I am now Surveyor of a party of Engineers running a line from here to Bellons Falls. Not the head of the party, his business is to go ahead and tell where to run the line, but the surveyor whose business it is to carry the instrument and run the line. And better than all that; as good luck would have it, the compases all happening to be out of order, I had to run a line all last week with a Transit. Thus giving me a still better opportunity
Completed

of using a more valuable and complicated instrument, and of course improving & advancing still faster. The "Old Man," A. R. Field Esq. the head of the party, is riding about , or looking about, most of the time, and I, of course have the cahrge of the business. The rest of the party are Jonathan Orcutt[?], one of the stoutest, hardest looking customers you ever saw, has been on the road three years, is as good a head chainman, Target, or Rodman, as any one can be, but without education can probably never get any higher. He is skillful, quick sighted, and correct, much depended upin in everything, but rather quick tempered, and somewhat ugly when angry. I manage as well as I can to keep the right side of him, and success very well; though I find he is not disposed to like me, perhaps does not like it very well that I a new comer am put above him.
Mr. F. A. Tenney, School Master of Gill,, Map., a pretty good sort of fellow, quite a scholar, slightly pedantic perhaps but his principal fault being that he cannot keep his mouth shut. I hardly ever saw one's tongue run so, and on every variety of subject. Why, especially if he happens to get an extra cup of tea. I believe he would rattle of[f] scraps of poetry & every thing else, all night long. He says he can repeat a couplet from any author of the English language! On the whole, he affords us much amusement, but whether he will ever make an Engineer I more than know. Francis Fisher, is an ignorant, stout, chapper, does, and never can be any thing better
Completed

Oct 31 to Nov 8
Rufus Holton of Northfield is a very good sort of fellow not being very long in the service, but promises to be a very useful one. These four made my party, except the "Old Man", as they call the head of the party.
A. R. Field Esq. is called a very fine man. I do not think very highly of him as an Engineer, he is a little short sighted, and that is as great a defect as once can have. He has however had a good deal of practice, and probably thinks himself much superior to some above him. Joseph A, Stephens is particularly a friend of hos, and his father I expect thinks Field has badly influences Joseph's religious opinions. Uncle & family, & Parsons & Hannah you know are, or call themselves, Evangelical Unitarians belong to the Religious Unitarians; are very religious as Wooster Parker said of the Universalist affairs; their religion consist in these things.
Field is a great admirer of Parker. Theodore Parker you know aWom some of the other Unitarians consider little better than an infidel. And in fat I think Field is but little better. And Joseph is slightly of the same sort. It is a sort of natural tendency of Unitarianism; if its believers get tired of trying to work out salvation by their own good works, they very naturally turn towards infidelity, perhaps a little afraid of it, the name at least, but in reality getting towards it.
How long I should stay between here & Bellon's Falls I know not, the last week we have stopped here at Brattleboro', This week we shall be at Putney; the next probably at Westminster, and the next perhaps at the Falls. That is if we are not before that called over upon the mountain, the the Bennington & Troy[?] Survey
Completed

This is the letter to Joseph continued.
Perhaps however with new sheets, its best to take up new subjects. Have you a boy? Is it Moses Greenleaf? How does he answer? and what is the prospect of his usefulness & Excellence, next year & hereafter? Do you expect S. M. Furber to be with you next season? What is the prospect for your next summer's business.
Glad to hear of it if you have an agreeable boarding place. Have Labaree & Son taken down the "Bangor Temperance House" sign? It ought to be pulled over their ears. How do you like Woodbury as a Chum? My best respects to him & any other friends if such there be. You ought to have given Labaree a few words of "your mind", when leaving him under such circumstances as you mention. If you were going to a public house to board at all, why did you not go to Varney's? as is that more expensive? How much does your board cost per week. You speak of being in Mass & N.Y. If so, why do you not visit here. It would do me considerable good to see you here. It would cost only 2. or three dollars from Boston here.
Is it an Irish Cook or Chamber girl, of whom you speak as co eater of pie with yourself? If not get acquainted fast as possible. As for political principles of the Whig & Democratic There is in reality & has been no difference. difference of principles is not has never been since 50 years the cause of difference in parties.
Completed

Writings of Charlotte Elizabeth of whom/which you speak I am quite unacquainted with. I think her a strong sectarian, Episcopalian i guess. Though I remember she was very religious. Somehow I have impression that are not just the thing. May be mistaken. Guess however thay are about of that half way medium class of writings under which most come, which I don't think much of reading. Neither strong meat nor good recreative matter, rather milk for babes order.
Fortnight ago today, Party of Engineers from Vt. Map [illegible] started for Surrey of route from Brattleboro' to Bellon's Falls. A. R. Field, Head. I. S. Metcalf Surveyor J. Orcult & F. A. Tenney Chainman; F. Fisher Chopper, R. H. Holton, Target & Chopper. To better the business for me, the compasses were out of order, & I had to use a Transit. Ten Field was called away & I was left head of all for three days. Rather a responsible, or difficult situation, Surveyor on a route entirely new without any ne to go ahead to look out the oute. Moreover, it was the worst place on the whole line worst country I every saw. However I made out better than I expected, better than Field expected And after we got out of the Dummerston Ravines I would not have given a snap[?] for Field to tell me the country ahead. See it for my
Completed

self, across those great thousand acre meadows.
I had reputation of an old surveyor when I came on the road, & I have never injured the reputation though it has been well tried; and in reality I had hardly ever used a compass. However I knew enough about it to learn without showing any ignorance; and I believe I am likely to make a really good surveyor, at least I had a considerable time up there. All the care & responsibility of the business & a crew of men, Books &c. to keep in order, and [lanes?] all to be plotted evenings.
I expect now not to go upon the mountain survey, but to remain on this road where I shall have a better chance in my respects. There I should be a good common hand. Here I shall have charge over others, but poorer men, though in a business I need more to learn -- Building a road not surveying it.
This has been Some meeting day. Great Whig or anti war party gain. I was invited to a whig glorification supper, but do not go as this letter shows.
I shall probably be most of this winter between Northfield & Brattleboro', perhaps located at Vernon?
I. S. Metcalf
Completed

As soon as you have a good chance. Believe it is the best thing for unclear.
$15.00
Mar. 8th, 1847 Monday Eve
Dear Brother Joseph,
I have just signed the Engineer's Pay Roll of St. unclear for the month of October, and received therefor $20.00 in addition to $14.00 board. Not very great wages, but I do not know as I better complain, it is five dollars or more better than new beginners generally receive. To be sure, I have done more than usual proportion of hard labor, having whenever there was opportunity, gone ahead in any or every laborious matter; and then a considerable part of the time, I have been using instruments & entrusted with business, for which one usually receives about double those wages. But then, I have had an unusually good chance & opportunity for improvement, for learning just? the things I want & need to learn. So that it would be better for me by far, even if I received no higher wages, or perhaps even, none at all. However, it will not be long, at this rate before I can set my own wages. Next summer, next spring, they will be pretty decent - perhaps. I wish I could send you the whole $20.00 dollars, and ten or fifteen more with it. I shall be obliged to have some clothing, as the colder weather is coming on, and shall be most particularly short even if I keep the V. So you will be obliged to wait in hopes I may sometime see another
Completed

"Pay Roll." Your full & excellent letter or letters were by me duly received on the evening of Friday last Mar. 5th and received too to my great gratification I had been long expecting letters both from you & from Milo. They both finally came together. Yours was partly written sometime ago, about the time I began to expect it. Do you show my letters to Elias? & to Ann? And why do they not write? You say as to seeing your relatives in Mass & with the utmost nonchalance & Sang froid to boot,] "probably I never shall" if you have got into to your old musty snail shell, & drawn your slime around you, and fairly dried or frozen in, is it yet absolutely certain that the sun never will shine, or the gentle rain, or the dews fall again, to soften you out? You enquire why I do not have some thinner & finer ruled paper to write letters on. It would be well. It is simply because I write on just what I have by me, perhaps what happens to be found at the desk, or in the bar room or R.R. or other office where I happen to write.   If Mt Grace is the least of all Mountains it is not one of the least extensive, or least beautiful prospects.   Am hardly prepared to agree with you that Potatoes "Were".  You Enquire if there is R.R. from Boston to Northfield.  The Vermont & Mass. R.R. "a part of which I am". was finished last August from the terminus of "Fitchburg R.R. at Fitchburg to Baldwinsville just now opened from there to Athol (through South Royalston, where the dreadful R.R. accident lately occurred) nearly done to mouth of Millers river, will be complete to Northfield sometime next spring, to Brattleboro Vt. in the course of the season.
Completed

Fitchburg R.N. Stock about the best in the world. holders doubled or quadrupled their money. Vt.XMo. now 45 1/2 to 80 or 90 fut. constantly gaining reputation. had to contend with greatest obstacles & adverse influences. If a new road is built across the mountain Vt.&Mo. will be equal to Fitchburg or better yet.
Politics. have I written you any thing thereof? the real if not then breaking up of Old party lines. Merely nominal. There is but one great question before the country. If Silas Albright had lived to be candidate for Pres. 9/10 of the Whigs of Mass. at least would have voted for him If Taylor is nominated all Southern Democrats as well as whigs vote for him. but No true Whigs at the north. Mass. at least. at least none who do not vote for baleb bushing for governor, in opposition from Geo. N. Briggs. You have too poor an opinion of folks in general. The worst thing I have against the Mercantile profession -- its tendency to harden the face of a man like a flint against his fellow man. -- to shut up and freeze down all those kind warm sympathies gushing from a true human heart, which honor, ennoble & exalt, as they purify and bless, the whole human existence. Fallen human nature is doubtless bad enough; Do not give up what you may almost call the only good thing about it.
Chief Engineer Edwards hired me. Monthly Pay Roll, looks out for the wages. Vt.&Mo. R.R. Co. is responsible. You say the World is well enough on some sunny day &c., It depends only on one's own mind to have all one's days sunny days
Completed

Oct 31 to Nov 8
About the 25th of Oct. Last past, you appear to have had quite a serious attack of the so called -- Blues! Miserable, frightful devils I expect they are. Am not subject to them myself. I was thinking while reading yours to give you a serious lecture upon these Blue Devils But now you have got over it I suppose the very best dose you could have would be copy of your effusions at that time, "in terrorism."
But seriously Joseph I believe it to be, not only perfectly needless, but absolutely wrong to give way to, or even to harbour at all such feelings, To be sure, you have trials troubles, vexations; disappointments, discouragement &c. &c. So have all. You may have a large share. Tis no reason for Blues If we were to make a general rule, it would be found that he who has the most of all these evils is the happy man in this life: far oftener at any rate than the contrary.
After all all these feelings, Blues &c. commonly have a physical rather than a mental or a moral origin. You have had too much labor, care & anxiety. too little recreation, of mind or body. Therein you have done wrong; no matter if circumstances did seem to require it. It was wrong. Contrary to the Laws, natural laws so called, of Him who created & nobly endowed mind & body. These laws broken bring penalties. you have mixed too little in Society, Society -- the Society of the intelligent 7 good of the other sex, is perhaps the best recreation of mind. The bow must not be always bent. I can study more in a year in 10 hours per diem than in 18. You or any body else can do more & better for some recreation. Duty -, Duty to yourself, to friends, to Creator, requires it. I advise you as a brother, to get acquainted more, & with Females, too. they are not all so much inferior or unworthy of acquaintance as you may imagine. Make up your mind also to get married
Completed

Joseph. This sheet is partly to you the other to Anne & a word to Eliab.
Thursday Dec. 2d. It is Thanksgiving Day in Vermont. but I do not happen to be there today. It is a very rainy day. but a time in the Northfield R.R. office. The President Alvah Crocker Esq. is about & some of the Directors full of all kinds of business. The Head Bookkeeper & Pay Masters of the Corporation are up here, paying off Irishmen &c. &c. by scores. Bills of all kinds for piles & sleepers, & plank & stone, and work & Board, and every thing else. Besides all this Engineers are up from below, with the Conn. River big bridge builders; drawing off plans, profiles, elevations, sections, beds, foundations, abutments piers, parapets, &c. &c. &c. of the bridge. it is rather a busy time for a rainy day. You may imagine that We underlings have to
Completed

made to support hundreds of tons weight, with no such thing as an Arch about it; merely this straight "truss work", perhaps near 200 feet span, and the largest timber in it seems inches thick! It speaks considerable for the inventive genius of pun Man.
Rail Road Bridges all over the country, I do not know but all over the world are made on the same pattern.
You have probably seen accounts, if I did not write it, of the falling of a Rail Road Bridge in this Road, in Royalston, a month since. first time it was crossed by a heavy loaded train. Six lives lost &c. It frightened people all over the world. In fact props were in the first excitement put under the span by the bridges in many places. If one of these bridges call fall, why not another, or all? But there can be no doubt of the Bridge principle. It has been tested and tried enough, if any thing can be enough. To return it now would be almost to overthrow every rail road in the world.
Well Joseph, your letter was duly received, and one from Sister Anne enclosed, last Monday. Dec. 6th. duly rec did I say? it had been for some reason or other more than a week on the way here. Enclosed in the letter were two blank half sheets of paper! (by mistake, or with some hidden meaning). At any rate they made the postage double. and moreover your Bangor P.M., either knowing better or worse the situation of Northfield, than other P.M. in Maine, considers it over 300 miles. and so the stage was .20 About the same time I got one from Milo - 5 cts. And I mail letter to any part of Maine from here for that.
However, I was glad enough to get the letter at that I had been expecting it for some time.
You thought my pay would be greater! Why you would con
Completed

sider it pretty well for one commencing Mercantile business to get at the rate of $400. per year. besides all that before the year is out I shall probably receive at the rate of $6.00 per year. That is perhaps I shall. And when I get two or three thousand per Annum the business will be better than yours! When the Western R.R. was built, its Engineer received $5000. per year.
Why do you not keep a fire in your stove? What a cold country that Down East of yours must be! Why here we have had only two or three cold days, and those only in the imagination of the Natives. I have not been cold. As for freezing up there appears no more prospect of such a thing than there was last May. The weather lately has been a succession of long heavy Rain Storms, clearing off warm & sunny for a day or two and then another.  Did your river really freeze up three weeks since? Neither ice nor snow here.
I hereby commission you to rub the ears of E.W. MetCalf soundly, and charge the same to my account. or send in your bill whenever you please.
You say you had no newspapers. Why. What is your Reading Room good for to you? It is every one's duty to keep informed of Public Affairs. Keep your feet dry
Shingle Trade to Northfield will probably not be much The place is small, its business less. Building going on. I know of none, except Paddy Shanties. Those are never shingled. Brattleboro, 12 ms. above is quite a large town, full of business. It is however in the midst of an extensive slate region. Slate probably is cheap there as any where in the world now.
Completed

The old Vermont Windham County Farms have their barns all slated. Moreover there is much lumber on the Connecticut river.  It come down from Bellow's Falls in rafts less than 1/2 mile long. unjointing at the rapids.  Their shingle bunches are enough to make a Down Easter laugh.  That Bangon shingles come to Springfield is a striking proof that the Conn. is not the Penobscot!  12 [?] below Gorenfield's quite a place.  if you can send shingles there own [?] are perfectly acquainted.  I should think Fitchburg would be a good shingle market.  Northfield has no Bank no business no building. If there were no Rail Road men about you would hardly find $100 in it except it might be in some old Woman's stocking! R.R. Sleepers [?] Man" are White Chestnut , seven & a half feet in length, six inches face & fill six inches." Said Sleepers are delivered here at twenty cents each.and [?] of said sleepers [graphic] [graphic] [graphic] [graphic]. Cedar would be preferred. Engineer [?] me doing this same request to know for what [?] you would contract to deliver such Sleepers at Charleston.
Say twenty or thirty thousand of them?  Come tell us what you can afford.  Delivered at Fitchburg R. R. Wharf Charleston.  As for your opinion of individual humanity I suppose it can not be otherwise.  It is the worst part of mercantile life.  One is brought in contact only with the worst part of human nature.  Of course is likely to form a poor opinion of it.
What has become of the Greenleaf Boy whom you expected in your store?  Which party did not suit?  I suppose when you were in Mass. of course you were in Boston.  Why did you not call upon Humphrey Stevens.  He and others, too. would not [like?] it very well if they knew you were [in?] Boston without seeing [him?].  You know his place do you not?  However I think likely he has given up [these] now is out of business just now I guess.  Have you been in a row lately?
Completed

Gaue.
Loee 2 1847,
Comm. Ris. Bridge. Salary. Sale
for shingles in northfield 
R R sleepes
Completed

Vt.&Mass R.R. Office Northfield
Vt.&Mass. R.R. Office.
Northfield. Dec. 22nd  47
Dear Brother
Yours of the 19th inst. dated at Bowd. Coll. came to my hands this morning. Several items and matters of fact therein contained, being noticed, I deem worthy of recurrence, and having this evening finished my day's work early; 'it is hardly yet nine by the clock'; I consider the occasion favorable for scribbling a few words of reply, while my mind is thereunto attracted.  Your letter is dated Bowd. Coll.  Very well for the occasion; though erroneous in point of fact, "Berry's" not being within the College Yard.  I am glad to hear you have been at Brunswick. It is always pleasant to have ones relatives & friends see the places we have seen: There is one more idea in common.  Strictures upon King Chapel & Brunswick Church. Your Criticism showing your habits of thought, and the circumstances under which your taste is formed. Your taste is undoubtedly a good one, severe, correct, and all that, as far as your own sphere is concerned. But upon College Chapels or even upon churches you get beyond it!  I should agree with you on the proportions of those buildings if designed for a Town Hall, an Exchange, or even a Court House. Mr. Upjohn is undoubtedly at least one of the first Architects in the U.S. Those buildings, both designed by him certainly do him credit. They are not Doric, that would be fit for
Completed

for a Town Hall, or Corinthian, appropriate for a Dancing Hall; unclear The style is a sort of modification of the Gothic, properly called the Romaic a favorite of the said Upjohn, and like the Gothic peculiarly appropriate for the house of God. Every cities' taste I believe assigns the Gothic with its pointed arches, its shadowy isles, it high windows, its spires piercing the skies, as the perfection of taste for the Temple of the Christian God. The Romaic with the same general character, the same severe proportions and lofty, heavenly grandeur is equally adapted to the same purpose, with the benefit of greater variety, and greater capacity of adaptedness to different circumstances of time, place, and purpose.  The 'effect' of the Tower of that Church is for me almost entirely unrivalled.
unclear is a good house." is it, indeed? There is a College in the town. You stop at the "Elm House" Portland. Is that the Temperance House. Theunclear whether it is the "Elm" "U.S." or "American" in it where I strop. What is the cause of the heavy failure of Jos. Jenkins Co.?
But the principal effect with which in vein I took pen at this time, in hand, was to, to scold at you a little. If, as you write, you found yourself delayed in Portland, unable to proceed upon your journey by your usual or proposed route, Why did you not take the Stage leaving Portland for Brunswick twice a day regular? or if you preferred it Charter a "team" of some other kind.  You were old enough to know that all things have their value, Gold & Silver, have, so have taters & shingle. You are old enough to know that Bones, Muscles, & health, have also a value you ought to know it. Even I, and I was duller at it than any person claiming common sense ought to be, have learned the lesson. The stage fare from Portland to Brunswick is usually one dollar, never over nine shillings. Suppose it were five dollars or ten. reckon that at its highest value. What is it compared with "stiff, sore & lame"  Appraising values any how, a piece of machinery like the human system, with such an Architect. So expensive, so perfectly finished, so nicely adjusted, so unrivalled in its uses, so astonishing in its adaptations; what is it "worth"?  How shall be estimated its careless or improper use? unclear use &c. until its joints dry & the edges irritated, the muscles stretched, stiff hard, & the nerves irritated & worn.  He who does this is not only careless & improvident, but wicked.
In pleasant weather, in the summer season, with a plenty of spare time, some money & a proper disposition, I would blame no one for walking The Country is at any time not very promising between P. & B.  I have walked it two or three times.  Did you take the Stage Road.? Nothing hardly but plain land is the Region. If in sight of the bay, it is
Completed

none the better(unclear phrase]] in winter scarcely any thing looks more dreary than the Sea or Sea Shore in winter. Where could have been the Good looking County. It looks bad enough in pleasant summer weather. as for farming, there is no such thing as fencing material in the county & the Soil does not bear bragging.
Second head of Scolding. I do not like your uncharitableness. Perhaps you call it " minding your own business". It is crabbedness. Why could you not like a decent feller, state the circumstances. When you left Bangor, & for what, how you left the people, & the unclear where, how, & for what you went, your success, prospects &c. In fact why should you not write whatever you knew about yourself or any body else, which you knew would interest me. Such a course would have been decent, reasonable, gentlemanly, and brotherly. Your course is to be sure better than not writing at all. But is it right to do well when you are so abundantly able to do better
My present condition and prospects are favorable. I am a Resident Engineer  at Northfield, now the principal office of the Vt. & Mass. R.R.  My success & advancement have been beyond my expectations, circumstances having been most propitious. The Engineer of this Road, Edwards, with whom I engaged, left this road.  I chose to remain with Mr Field with whom I have been most of the time. Under Johnson,k the new Chief Engineer, Mr

Field is First Assistant & in fact has almost entire charge this end of the line. I have, as I said, been with Field abou[t] since I came on; have aquiredhis confidence, respect & [edge of page missing]ship. He has come to consider that I am always in the [edge missing] can succeed in doing whatever I undertake, and [edge missing] my opinion is one that can safely be followed, in fact is so {edge missing} to rely upon me in things he does not himself understand, whic[h][edge missing} know is considerable for some men. My advancement [edge missing] to myself almost surprising. A friend of mine, who graduated [edge missing] Bowd a year before, with highest honors, President of a College Society went into Engineering St Lawrence Lewiston Falls & Waterville. He has [edge missing] the [indecipherable] for the year almost it is usual I expected it; should perhaps have been [edge missing] And indeed I am not sure that for him who has time enough it [edge missing] all the better to acquire by long practice & habit, a a minute acqua[intance?] with the minor details, as the foundation of a thorough

Pay roll has not yet come round the second time.  Changes of neess? & having disarranged matters.  Pay day for the two months probably be along about Jan. 1st.  I am given to understand that wages are $40. per month, probably will be no higher than that until ng, although Mr? Field tells me he is going to resighn this division to [[]] and I probably have, with a little assistance or oversight from his about [[]] are & responsibility of a $600, 800 a year Engineer.  However you have business? to say any thing of small wages.  In you Mercantile line, you would iden? $400 a year, $99? per month good wages.  I had that the first Mo. at the rate of $480 per year.  Next summer probably $300 for six months. t? the best part of my situation is my advantages for improvement. lace? in the Northfield is now the principal office of this RailRoad. ? is no small advantage to a young Engineer.  Better yet for me he? being on the spot, and having to do with the building of this t? Bridge across the Connecticut River to this place, which is to be fully al?, by contract superior, to any thing of the kind in Ill? built by the best builders in the country.  Why the chance for an Engineer invaluable.  I do not know as I would take a thousand dolls for it. In? my next I hope I shall have the pleasure of remitting the balance? of my debt to you; I hope you have not felt the want. [[]] you please to write frequently, particularly, and much.

Northfield. Jan. 12th. 1848.
Dear Brother
Your last letter was received I believe on New Years Eve. It contained a request that I would answer it about Jan 1st. so as to renew the system. I would gladly have done so, but as I had written you twice within a shortly, I thought it best to wait at least until I obtained some thing to enclose to render it worth the Postage. Said something has been expected daily ever since. it has not yet arrived. Soon afterwards I will endeavor to dispatch this now begun upon sheet.
Simultaneous with the reception of yours was that of one from Nancy, inviting me to present myself at her Wedding which is to take place tomorrow Eve. That I cannot so do is at present a considerable source of mourning to me. 
I am much obliged to you for the unusual amount of fact on the first page of your letter, namely the incident of your late journey. How does your frozen ear trouble you? How many weeks did it take you to - Outside Creditors are all except a few 'friends perhaps,' specially secured.
Whatever the other effects of the Lyceum difficulties may be, it has probably benefitted Dr. Pomroy. I do not mean his reputation, for I know nothing of the effect there upon; but it was a good thing to stir him up. Your quotation from Festus just now strikes me. I should not say "sorrow is the base of all great thoughts. but sorrow is the spur inciting the thought of the Enlarged Mind. L. F. Pomroy D.D. is a large man but for years the even easy tenor of his life has lacked the spur which trouble, vexation, corners, embarrasments - sorrow would give.
Your remarks upon correspondence are excellent. I have not just now thought enough about me to frame an excuse for my deficiencies. It is very natural, for one constantly occupied with with thoughts of very different things, when trying to write letters, the mind feeling that should be only a change, as an unbending, or relaxation, to write many words and few thoughts.
Completed

A Quotation in your letter strikes me as not always true. My thoughts are much disposed to 'tangle "passing o'er the life", usually.
Just now 'it is Thursday Eve,' while I think of it, do you remember a Miss Stevens, from Guilford Center, at Foxcroft Academy? A Mr. Piper whom with I here became acquainted, lately informed me that his wife having formerly been such a Miss Stevens of Guilford, & attended said Academy, thought she had formerly known me or those of my name there.  Pressingly invited I this evening have called. Said Mrs. P. is a very pleasant lady; called one of the first of Northfield. She was probably at school at F. when you were first under the administration of Messrs. Thurston & Dole. perhaps afterward.
You speak of my remarks upon Connecticut River Bridge at Northfield. The contract has a specification so this effect.now copied from original document in my house - "In fine all the Materials & mechanical labor on said bridge to be of the best quality, and superior to that of any railroad structure in New England." Is that strange or impossible? You speak of "stone or iron bridges." We have an abundance of just such stone arches as you speak of on this road, as well as every where else. We do not call them "bridges." They are "Culverts" of different kinds "Arch Culverts" perhaps; over brooks, roads &c. This is a "Bridge" you may call it a stone, iron, or wood.  The masonry granite will be founded upon about 1000 piles. In the 4 Abutments & 3 piers there will probably be perhaps 5000 Perches of hammered Stone, '25 cubic feet to unclear no course to be less than 20 inches in thickness &c&. "In fine the granite & workmanship of the masonry to be superior to my Railroad Masonry, Wet or dry, in R.E." The Wood ('Iron'), is to be "Howes Patent" Truss work. - regular Rail Road bridge with all improvements, and an unusual amount of iron work. The contract is very minute, some ten or dozen pages, sums up with the expression I quoted you. Height of Bridge from top of piles from 60 to 70 feet. As for the cost, it would probably be less than such a bridge at Bangor. One of the best Quarries in the World, where they have started 3000 tons of stone
Completed

at a blast, and clears square as a brick, within 4 miles. All down hill. Timber abundant. You speak of the space to be filled at the Ends. The bridge builders have nothing to do with moving Earth. It would be something of an item, an embankment 20 or 30 feet for two or three thousand feet in length.
You ask if the R.R. bridges are covered bridges. For R.R. bridges usually not. They may be or not, as it pleases. The general plan patent is the same in all. different modifications.
Postage on letters to Bangor, I think ought not to be double. The ordinary Mail route via Railroads & Boston may be two or three miles over the Legal 300. But there are certainly Mail routes via Keene & Portsmouth, which would be very much less. I think the fault must be in your Gen. Miller. as only Bangor letters are to me thus charged. Milo letters single.
You say the name of the new Bank in Bangor is nearly the same as unclear. Which letter or letters of said name do they alter? is it amended as well as altered? I am impatient to receive the Poetical productions of which you speak; hope they will come by the earliest opportunity. Did I tell you that I had received a pressing invitation to Lecture before the Warwick Lyceum? I am however both to much engaged in other matters, and to intellectually indolent  in any matters not connected with my business, which I am obliged to enter into, to attempt any such thing.
The Pressure of the Money Market is Awful. To raise money here abouts they say is imposible. (sic)  Stock holders will not pay in assessments December estimates on Vt. & Mass. were a few days since met by Sixty days Drafts. These Drafts, best paper possible. they find it impossible to get Cashed, discounted, at Banks of City or Country. While a few months since One did not need go to the Banks, They would send 50 ms. their agents to cash Drafts for Contractors. What the poor Contractors will do I know not. dependent of course upon these Monthly estimates to pay men and all expenses. They have already reduced wages of laborers to $.70 per day, going lower. How the poor beings live I hardly see.
Written upside down across the top:
Since the 1st of Jan we have been expecting our Pay Roll cashed. I do not mean

July [2?] 1845  Mr. Perkins Prest.  Of which $15.00 is you. on Note, and interest probably some.  Then that [Value?] yours which I have.  If ther is "any thing over" the "Six Lectures on the Uses of the Lungs" by Samuel Sheldon. If the book has another title it is 'Causes & Cure of [Consum?].  Remember, I am particular about the book.  It may save [valu?] Probable cost $.50 cent, on thence forward to a dollar.
I am impatient to hear how you survive these money  It [lev?] affirmed to be positively awful.  Nothing like it [ev?] [kn?] Unfinished Rail roads are "all of a heap". moving [?] inches short as much as possible on this road they have [even?]
missed part of the Engineering Corps.  I may congratula myself upon being retained while others longer in servi who might reasonably be supposed better are discharged.  However the las summer is that the prospect is they will be [?] to weather it , will have to stop altogether.  That would course throw Engineer as well as all others out of Employ, and might expect to see me down East before long.  But I guess they will continue somehow to [heep?] along, and [?]
probably remain if any do. If I thought a total [Sqush?] probable I do not know but I should send you $40. instead of $25.00 or #0.00 to purchase of Mathematical [Instrument?] Engineer Books &e.  Perhaps I better not do it until Times are surer. Pray write to me soon, on  or before the 1st [Prox.?]   This letter is not worth much, except for the  X X  but it {?] have to go.  I will try to do better another time Please write soon, send on the  [Poctical Effucions?] of which you note &e.  Yours, [?] J. [?]

Northfield Mass. Feb. 6th 1848
Dear Brother
On returning last eve to Northfield, after my peregrinations of the week through forest, fields, and many snows, I found among others, an exceeding letter from thee, with the excellent and much contents of which, my mind for the evening and night being filled, thereto, after the accustomed services of the day & sanctuary, hidden by string most readily and naturally recur. The probability now being that the ensuing week, like its immediate predecessor, will by me spent away from my habitual place of abode, and under such circumstances as to put all thoughts of correspondence at considerable distance from my mind; therefore being seated take I pen in hand.
Very many matters in thy Epistle are every way worthy of minute attention, and careful, thoughtful reply. Whether I shall have time, opportunity, or ability to give such as they deserve is at best doubtful.
Firstly, however, let me introduce here that which in glancing at your letter comes first to mind. Did you ever read a Tragedy in five acts, called "Julius Caesar" written long time ago by one William Shakespeare, King of English? If so, do you remember the remarks put in the mouth of the Hero of the Tragedy respecting a certain Caius Cassius? The book which contains it may be known in Northfield, but at any rate I do not See it; as for quoting from Memory; I might about as well depend upon memory for a Table of Logarithms as for the words of any Author, Ancient or Modern. However, in the expression to which I allude, Julius would beware of that "lean Cassius" as a man who "thinks too much." Now the thought has struck me that if ever a man was formidable on that score, your self might well be dreaded. Whether or not you are "lean as Cassius", not having seen
Completed

either lately, I cannot well say. At any rate, I have come to the conclusion that you are a "thinking Man". Now I have quite a large acquaintance among young men, many of them men of Education, of refined, cultivated, and well disciplined minds, so called; but it does not word not shown occur to me that I would be willing to warrant any one of them really thinking as much in one week as you do in one day. And as for myself, who from advantages of education, extensive & varied reading, in several respects, fair opportunities: might reasonably be expected, "word hidden for comparison, I hope no reason for judging that I think as normal in one month, or have day in the month last past, as you appear to one hour: that is, when the thinking mood comes over you.
Now I think of it, there is in your letter, if I can find it, a passage my mental indolence. I do most fully, and most heartily confess the charge. It is a thing which has troubled me a good deal. It is a matter upon which I have really thought, or tried, or pretended, to think, more or less, occasionally. I have tried to imagine a cause, or a reason. I have been half flattering myself with the idea that perhaps as I had been for three or four years mostly occupied intellectually rather than physically, it was sometimes natural, if not reasonable, that the Mind should claim a space of rest, of relaxation from constant exertion. But I do not know as the flimsy defense would stand against your argument and theory. Still some things my experience would appear to confirm such an idea, I mean an idea that the mind may gain strength and ability for exertion from inactivity. E.g. you and I both when very young in Boston were precocious, prematurely scholars & readers. Now do you believe that if we had remained there under similar circumstances that should have ever matured into sound minds, eve as we now are? Was not the perfect change, relaxation, in fact the full giving up of that usually called Mental Culture, was it not necessary to further health development? I was not probably as good a scholar when I first went to Bangor to School
Completed

when we left Boston. Was not my mind stronger & better developed? My memory of course serves me little. In another case it does much. 1840 I left Bangor, after a year or two of hard study, my mind full of Latin & Greek; my brain stretched with thinking all it was able to think: word cut it did not amount to much at that. And a season of move Mental indolence & inactivity than followed in my mind words cut one has experienced. But how was it? did my mental energies in that season of inactivity, rust out and decay away? No: When I look back it hardly seems possible that two or three years could make so much difference, could so much, bring forth, develope (sic), & strengthen the intellectual powers. I can hardly realize it the same mind I carried from Bangor, which accompanied me to Foxcroft and to the halls of Old Bowdoin
I return to your letter. You ask my opinion of Mexican Affairs I am absolutely and diametrically opposed to the present War on all grounds and points; its commencement, its unclear, its honors, its glories, its reaword cut off, its causes, its effects, its prospects, its future progress, its all. But you ask how to get out of the scrape. It becomes me not to say. unclear disagree. The mightiest minds of the Country, perhaps of the world, have brought forward their plans, different plans. John & Henry & Daniel have spoken: their arguments I may not gainsay, their facts I cannot dispute. If they do not agree upon conclusions, am I competent to decide. The word, I hope you do not use in its common, universal sense. Honor, National honor. Private honor is usually understood, even that, Old Falstaff told it nearer the truth than the ten thousands that have laughed at him. But National honor; what is it. - the falsest, meanest thing that man - man, the politician - has ever invented, the abominable pretence of governments, the ridiculous bugbear of foolish subjects; the worst enemy of humanity - let the very word be accursed among peoples.
Completed

The very word itself is a lie its idea is the meanest folly, the cut word robbery and Murder.
You use the word in a different sense; but in such sense such a thing never existed. An honorable government cut word would never saw: it is a moral impossibility.
Man, single man, is a moral being, he may cut word an upright honorable being. But thoo? men together cut word of them is a moral being, together they are not, cannot be moral being. The old proverbe " Corporatives have no cut word is but an axiom. If true of a body corporate, what cut word it be of a body politic? A nation can no more have cut word conscience than a ten penny nail can have a human heart.

       What is a Whig? What is a Democrat? What is Democracy? What are Whig Principles? Who can answer these questions? It is said that all Educated men without cut word, prejudice, or interest to the contrary are Whigs in this Country.

It is certain that the large majority of Educated men are Whigs, cut word the Boston Post would find fault with Education itself on those grounds
Does Whig mean one opposed to Democracy? If so I am one heartily I am not a Democrat even in the best sense of the word. I cannot agree with either Motto "The largest liberty to all". "The government is best when governs least". Is the late great Argument of Danl Webster before the Supreme Court on the Rhode Island case, against Hallett.- are cut word arguments Whig principles versus the Democracy of Hallett? But cut word Webster is newer a Democrat than I am; that is if he utters his real sentiments. Few Public men do when they speak to the people. Their true sentiments would not please the people. Suppose I wanted to go to Congress or wanted cut word other unclear in gift of people. How would it do to express my true sentiments. why they might startle even you. Democracy is a government of the people. It is a name dear to the people of this country, as it was to the people of Greece and Rome. It is the mightiest word in the vocabulary of the Demagogue; It has always been.
But there are three things in which I have not the slightest faith. The Right of cut word people to govern themselves. The ability of the people governing themselves, the cut word of the people governing themselves. Three mighty things rise up in my wind against Democracy. The Word of God, Human Nature. The History of the World.
I believe I am not a Monarchist. Though I believe that with one condition an Absolute Monarchy would the best possible of human Governments.
I believe I am a Republican, fully so. A Republic is the form of Gov. I unclear cut word as a perfect one; it cannot be in this world. or as true in any theory. But all things  considered the best, that is the one must susceptible of improvement, and best fitted to this world.
A Republican form of Gov. is perhaps the wisest & boldest scheme of man. It is remedy Evils by Evils. A mighty scheme  of checks & balances.
Completed

[[]]r remarks upon a Mexican Great Man are pretty good, perhaps somewhat ?tured with "Carlyleism"  You look upon Europe as requiring a great ?  Where? It has now at least one Great Man.  Nicholas
[[]]ur ideas upon Sea Shore scenes versus summer landscapes are well expressed and perhaps good, but I cannot rce? with them fully.  The warm bright meadow glittering in sunlight, the happy [[]]ve enlivened by the music of birds & breezes, the quiet river bank, ar not all deceitful? shine, deceitful show  They are true pictures.  They are the hand writing of him who cannot lie.  This world is not all a gloomy prison house of mind. It? is a bright & a beautiful world, full of objects of gratitude and contentment.  To? be sure the roses have thorns, and the meadows have thistles & briars, but shall I not enjoy the sweetness of the rose because I may prick my finger with the thorn?  Shall I not walk the meadow because I may, if I go barefoot, hurt my foot with? a thistle?  I say it is man's duty to be happy in this world.  He is deating? the designs of God if he is not.  He should, it is true, be careful of the thorns, but he should go confidently forward to gather the roses.
To understand Drawing would certainly be great apistance?.  A knowledge of perspective must be requisite in drafting buildings especially.  I think I must endeavor to acquire such knowledge, though very many engineers do not.  An engineer is not necessarily a real Draftsman, or a Draftsman an Engineer.
As for politics; I "read the papers".  As an American I am interested in the political affairs of U.S.A. as a man & a scholar in those of Europe & the world.
You say my December prospects seem shaded.  I do not know.  It is hard times to be sure; but them? feel it, not I.  I have gone steadily onward in prosperity: my wages, my responsibilities, my prospects constantly increasing and brightening.  My success (spite of Mental Indolence) has been perfect, beyond my expectations or even hopes.
Sat. eve. Feb. 12th.  Well we have got back from Brattleboro.  It has been a very cold week, and people have complained bitterly of the cold. I have been extremely comfortable and laughed at the rest about "Down East Weather".  The fact is I am tough.  I have the coldest business too as instrumentalist, standing still about all the time.  The day though I pulled off coat I showed Casy Seamfes? how to cut trees.
Completed

Jos. M. Metcalf. I think that as a writer you possess considerable merits. Whether you excel most in prose or poetry, I shall not undertake to decide. Your prose writings, as far as I have seen them, certainly exhibit a considerable and very commendable degree both of vigor and excellence of thought, and of correctness and terseness of style. They show also, in my opinion, what, in a young writer, is especially valuable, a capability of improvement. They show a vigorous and well disciplined mind, capable of active thought, and also of acquiring the power or faculty of illustrating and moulding that thought, forming it into those shapes and sounds of strength and beauty which make it truly valuable. 
What you  most need appears to me to be a more extended knowledge of general literature, a fuller acquaintance with the most valuable writers. -- a study of them, not merely either as a seeker of thought, of ideas, but an acquaintance with such writings as mediums of thought, as styles. You perhaps lack, in ease & beauty of expression, in aptness and power of illustration. It is not the mere statement of fact or arguments which is especially valuable; it is rather the dressing up, comparing and illustrating those facts and arguments so as to make them not please the ear alone, but excite the attention, while they please the mind, take it captive by a sort of insensible power which -- 
There I have forgot what I was last writing. Your practical productions, I suppose those pieces in your last were yours, I should think had the same excellence & same defects defect which I have mentioned above. By the way I am no judge of poetry, and entirely unable to criticise it. I did once try to write verses 
Written upside down across the top:
I had a letter from Milo informing me of the great event, birth of a "son and heir", as Lucy has it, to the "house of Rich."  Lucy has been recently in Bangor. What think of her health.
Completed

though you well know I never could, but I gave it up entirely long ago. Do not know as I have tried to write a rhyme since my first year at Bowdoin, Do not know as I ever shall -- without I should happen to fall in love --
However, I think those pieces of yours really have considerable merit. The thought is good, thought should never be sacrificed to unclear. I have lost my taste for rhyme in a great measure. it unclear poetry to have a line put in merely to make a rhyme, as is too frequently the case. My taste in these matters is very different now from formerly. It is now only thought & metre I care for. The longest of those pieces I like. Its moral is good, as well as its intellectual, & harmonie. (sic)  "Slaughtered sons, victims of cut off that expression, though it may be strictly correct, would hardly seem so at first to most. Mars has acquired so much notoriety as a War God, that people generally look with distrust upon the pretentions of any other, except it be some old Scandinavian Scamp or other. I believe I like the cut off verses near the end best of that piece, or part of the long ones before. unclear or two line I marked. Leaving out 4 or 5 lines, the long lines with the short ones, and the last 12 for a moral, I like very well.
"The Gray Horse" is quite smooth and pretty, is of that class of poetry where melody & beauty of expression should be sought rather than thought: pleasure rather than instruction, You know too I am in favor of such things. It is in good taste, too, without she makes too much fuss about it. 
The other piece, would perhaps by some be called the best. The first stanza reminds me of something of Longfellow's, I cannot now tell what, perhaps it would be better withouth the last two lines though
